title: 110_s2006
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" and provides disaster assistance for power transmission and distribution facilities. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act defines private or investor-owned power facilities as privately-owned transmission or distribution facilities providing electric or natural gas service to retail customers. Contributions are subject to conditions outlined in the Act. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act defines private or investor-owned power facilities as privately-owned transmission or distribution facilities providing electric or natural gas service to retail customers. Assistance is provided to owners of such facilities for repair, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement after a major disaster, subject to specific conditions. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act provides assistance to owners of private or investor-owned power facilities for repair, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement after a major disaster, with specific conditions related to previous major disasters. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act provides assistance to owners of private or investor-owned power facilities for repair, restoration, or replacement after a major disaster, with specific conditions related to previous disasters. This includes requirements such as costs exceeding $2,500 per retail customer, total costs exceeding $500,000,000, and a significant impact on the local population. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act offers aid to private or investor-owned power facilities post major disasters, with conditions like costs exceeding $500,000,000 and a significant impact on local population. Owners meeting requirements can apply for Federal assistance within 30 days of disaster declaration. Owners of private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster can apply for Federal assistance within 30 days of the disaster declaration or after contributing $10,000,000 towards repair costs. Federal assistance is limited to costs exceeding $10,000,000 directly incurred by the owner. Costs are aggregated to determine eligibility for assistance. Owners of private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster can apply for Federal assistance within 30 days of the disaster declaration or after contributing $10,000,000 towards repair costs. Federal assistance is limited to costs exceeding $10,000,000 directly incurred by the owner, and costs are aggregated to determine eligibility for assistance. The President must approve or disapprove applications within 30 days. The Federal share for assistance includes private or investor-owned power facilities. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities for federal assistance. Owners of these facilities can opt for a contribution in lieu of repair costs if it's deemed not in the public interest to restore the facility. The contribution amount is 75% of the Federal estimate for repair costs. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities for federal assistance. Owners of these facilities can opt for a contribution in lieu of repair costs, amounting to 75% of the Federal estimate for repair costs. The funds can be used for repairing, restoring, or expanding power facilities, constructing new facilities, or funding hazard mitigation measures. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities for federal assistance. Eligible costs now cover public facilities, private nonprofit facilities, and private or investor-owned power facilities. The Secretary of Homeland Security must create regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment to implement the Act and its amendments. The Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment, with regulations under Section 3 effective immediately.
